`TempDirectory` already attempts to make all files writable when deleting them fails. It sounds like we should try to make folders executable as well. Would you be interested in submitting a PR for that?

Regarding the API status: don't worry! We know it's widely used so we won't just delete it without providing a migration path. At this point there are no plans to remove it.

> `TempDirectory` already attempts to make all files writable when deleting them fails. 

Oh that's good to know, it may be worthwhile to add that to the documentation at some point.

> Regarding the API status: don't worry! We know it's widely used so we won't just delete it without providing a migration path. At this point there are no plans to remove it.

I will be sleeping much better tonight :wink:

> It sounds like we should try to make folders executable as well. Would you be interested in submitting a PR for that?

Interested, yes definitely, would be a great honor to contribute here. But at the moment i'm at the limits regarding my energy and time resources. If you could point me at the bit in the code that tries to make everything writable again that may help me (or someone else) a lot in taking this up as i assume that'd be the right spot to make it reset any executable flags as well. If i find some time to look into it, i'll report back when i start working on it.

> TempDirectory already attempts to make all files writable when deleting them fails.

I have done some testing on this and i've found (at least on my linux ext4 filesystem) that this is never necessary ‚Äì `TempDir` can be deleted no matter what the permissions are on the *files* contained in it. Having said that, i tested that by setting a debug point and then deleting "by hand", so i understand this may be a different from the JDK runtime perspective.

> It sounds like we should try to make folders executable as well.

It's also about making folders writable again ‚Äì including the `TempDir` itself. I will do some testing and come up with a matrix what combinations throw an exception when Junit tries to close its context. Currently using version 5.5.2 ‚Äì i guess i should go to latest 5.7.x to get the full picture, correct?

> If you could point me at the bit in the code that tries to make everything writable again that may help me (or someone else) a lot in taking this up as i assume that'd be the right spot to make it reset any executable flags as well.

Sure thing:

https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/267ce626491b02a86af7fb94191313adb8959f8e/junit-jupiter-engine/src/main/java/org/junit/jupiter/engine/extension/TempDirectory.java#L220-L249

> I have done some testing on this and i've found (at least on my linux ext4 filesystem) that this is never necessary

IIRC the change was introduced for filesystems on Windows.

> Currently using version 5.5.2 ‚Äì i guess i should go to latest 5.7.x to get the full picture, correct?

Yes, the code above was introduced for 5.7.x.

issue.body:
After Marc Philipp implemented the `@TempDir` extension in Pioneer, it was later also added to Jupiter. It didn't (and as of September 2020 doesn't) support custom file systems, but other than that is more feature-rich than Pioneer's variant. This creates an unpleasant situation where there are two extensions that solve the same problem with the same approach, but slightly different feature sets (and an identical name to boot).

That said, there are a lot of feature requests for Jupiter's variant (‚ö†Ô∏è _some of these are already implemented!_ ‚ö†Ô∏è):

* [Multiple declarations of `@TempDir` in same parameter list or class declaration should fail](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2219)
* [Support @TempDir on constructor parameters](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1754)
* [Introduce cleanup mode in @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1814)
* [Multiple @TempDirs should result in multiple directories](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1967)
* [Provide support for setting a custom parent directory for @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2088)
* [Support disabling cleanup for @TempDir](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2159)
* [Support custom file system for `@TempDir`](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2400)
* [Make `@TempDir` restore mint permissions before closing context to avoid `AccessDeniedException`](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/2609)

After evaluating the situation in #277, we decided to remove the extension before the 1.0 release with the goal to look for a better solution to the problem in the future (i.e. this issue). So the task is to come up with a temporary directory (or, more generally temporary resource) extension that covers _more_ than what Jupiter does, possibly with an approach that makes different trade-offs (so users of Jupiter and Pioneer have more choices to solve their specific problem).

One interesting proof of concept to look at is @sormuras': [1](https://github.com/sormuras/brahms#temporary-directory-as-resource), [2](https://github.com/sormuras/brahms/blob/master/src/test/java/integration/resource/ChickenAndEggTests.java)

Thanks for the clarification @marcphilipp ‚Äì i upgraded to 5.7.2 now and can confirm that the above code works like a charm and resets writable permissions of the `@tempDir` itself as well as contained directories (note to self - when picking this up, i should also test for 2nd-level directories). Hence i could already remove cruft code for those tests cases, very nice indeed :smile: 

However i can confirm that the issue description holds true, as not only the executable-flag needs to be restored, but also the readable-flag. Otherwise, for instance when a test removes the readable-flag from the `TempDir`, it currently also triggers `AccessDeniedException`.

@marcphilipp & others i've written the tests for the above matrix and added them in e8c1f5217c. Then i tried to piggyback on to the `makeWritableAndTryToDeleteAgain` (making it effectively a `resetPermissionsAndTryToDeleteAgain` method) in 6df322747a.

However, the problem seems to be that for all test cases throwing an `AccessDeniedException` as seen in the test matrix above, they never throw an `IOException` (as a matter of fact, no `Exception` at all) in the `deleteAndContinue`-method of the `SimpleFileVisitor`, so fixing permissions at that point in the flow doesn't do the job. You can debug yourself if you enable the tests i created in e8c1f5217c, then set a breakpoint where the `IOException` is caught ([Line 211](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/pull/2624/commits/45563030855676b112847b05dad5df109fae61b3#diff-3f71fb375a592361209258d7aacc6786cc8009617db497c5bcf19ec467cfc6e2R211) and you'll find that it only gets reached 11 times ‚Äì these are the 11 successful cases in column one of the test case matrix above.
